case_name: Partnership concern (manufacture of pharmaceutical products) v. Retrenched workmen

facts.text: The appellant is a partnership concern carrying on business in the manufacture of pharmaceutical products.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a partnership companycern carrying on business in the manufacture of pharmaceutical products.

facts.text: There was a gratuity scheme in force in the appellant-concern for a long time.

anchor.surface_text: There was a gratuity scheme in force in the appellant-concern for a long time.

facts.text: This scheme was modified by an award of the industrial tribunal dated August 18, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: This scheme was modified by an award of the industrial tribunal dated August 18, 1952  hereinafter called the Award , and since then the modified scheme has been in force.

facts.text: The financial condition of the appellant deteriorated.

anchor.surface_text: The financial companydition of the appellant deteriorated and companysequently, it was companypelled to retrench a number of workmen.

facts.text: The appellant applied to the Appellate Tribunal under s. 22 of the Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, No. XLVIII of 1950, for permission to retrench 89 workmen.

anchor.surface_text: It, therefore, applied to the Appellate Tribunal under s. 22 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act  No. XLVIII of 1950 , for permission to retrench 89 workmen.

facts.text: The Appellate Tribunal granted permission for retrenchment of 75 workmen only.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal granted permission for retrenchment of 75 workmen only.

facts.text: The appellant retrenched the workmen and paid them compensation as provided in s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, after obtaining such permission, the appellant retrenched the workmen and paid them companypensation as provided in 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: A dispute was raised by the retrenched workmen through the union for gratuity on retrenchment under the award.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon a dispute was raised by the retrenched workmen through the union in existence in the appellant-concern for gratuity on retrenchment under the award.

facts.text: This dispute was referred to the Second Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, on March 23, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was referred to the Second Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, on March 23, 1956, for adjudication in the following terms

facts.text: Reference terms: Whether the seventy-five retrenched employees (as per attached list) are entitled to gratuity in addition to retrenchment benefits?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the seventy-five retrenched employees  as per attached list  are entitled to gratuity in addition to retrenchment benefits ?

facts.text: The Industrial Tribunal concluded that the retrenched workmen were only entitled to relief under s. 25F of the Act and not to any gratuity under the Award over and above the compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal came to the companyclusion that the retrenched workmen were only entitled to relief as provided under s. 25F of the Act and were number entitled to any gratuity under the Award over and above the companypensation payable to them under the Act.

facts.text: Workmen appealed to the Appellate Tribunal, which allowed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Then followed an appeal by the workmen to the Appellate Tribunal which was allowed.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held that the workmen were entitled to gratuity under the Award, as gratuity benefit therein was not a retrenchment benefit.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal held that the workmen were entitled to gratuity under the Award, as gratuity benefit therein was number a retrenchment benefit.

facts.text: The appellant applied for special leave to appeal, which was granted.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for special leave to appeal, which was granted and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: The Award provides gratuity scheme for cases of retrenchment or termination of service by the company for any reason other than misconduct or for cases of resignation with consent of the management.

anchor.surface_text: The following gratuity scheme shall be for cases of retrenchment or termination of service by the companypany for any reason other than misconduct or for cases of resignation with the companysent of the management.

facts.text: Gratuity up to a maximum of 15 months basic pay.

anchor.surface_text: The gratuity will be paid up to a maximum of 15 months basic pay at the following rates.

facts.text: Period of service to qualify for gratuity is one year.

anchor.surface_text: The period of service to qualify for the gratuity shall be on year.

facts.text: No gratuity payable before completion of one year of service.

anchor.surface_text: and that numbergratuity would be payable before the companypletion of one year of service

issues.text: Whether the seventy-five retrenched employees as per attached list are entitled to gratuity in addition to retrenchment benefits?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the seventy-five retrenched employees  as per attached list  are entitled to gratuity in addition to retrenchment benefits ?

issues.text: whether the retrenched workmen are entitled under the Award to gratuity provided therein in addition to retrenchment benefit under s. 25F of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The sole question, therefore for determination in this appeal is whether the retrenched workmen are entitled under the Award to gratuity provided therein in addition to retrenchment benefit under s. 25F of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the seventy-five retrenched employees  as per attached list  are entitled to gratuity in addition to retrenchment benefits ?

arguments.court_reasoning: Gratuity under Award is retrenchment compensation equivalent to s.25F, already paid; no double payment

arguments.claim: The retrenched workmen were only entitled to relief as provided under s. 25F of the Act and were not entitled to any gratuity under the Award over and above the compensation payable to them under the Act

arguments.court_reasoning: Industrial Tribunal correctly held scheme of Award same as s.25F compensation and s.25F provisions better

arguments.claim: The workmen were entitled to gratuity under the Award, as gratuity benefit therein was not a retrenchment benefit

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal held that the workmen were entitled to gratuity under the Award, as gratuity benefit therein was not a retrenchment benefit.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tuity used in the Award and it seems to think that gratuity on retrenchment is something different from companypensation on retrenchment. We are of op

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellate Tribunal erroneously focused on label 'gratuity'; substance is retrenchment compensation; no justification for double payment

arguments.claim: The general question considered in Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. Workmen, but special considerations arise on terms of particular awards

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for special leave to appeal, which was granted and that is how the matter has come up before us. The general question has been considered by this Court in the Indian Hume Pipe Company Limited v. Its Workmen  1960  2  S.C.R. 32 , judgment which is being delivered today.

arguments.claim: The Award is a composite scheme providing gratuity for retrenchment, termination other than misconduct, or resignation with consent

anchor.surface_text: The following gratuity scheme shall be for cases of retrenchment or termination of service by the company for any reason other than misconduct or for cases of resignation with the consent of the management. The gratuity will be paid up to a maximum of 15 months basic pay at the following rates.

arguments.claim: The name 'gratuity' given to payment on retrenchment is not material; the nature is compensation for retrenchment

anchor.surface_text: Though the word gratuity has been used to cover all these three cases, it is clear that cases of retrenchment as such are also covered by the Award and payment to workmen retrenched has been called gratuity. The name give to the payment is, however, not material and it is the nature of the payment that has to be looked into.

arguments.claim: On fair and reasonable construction of the Award, retrenched workman gets only compensation for retrenchment, not gratuity properly so called

anchor.surface_text: and that no gratuity would be payable before the completion of one year of service and that persons discharged for misconduct would not be entitled to any gratuity. ... In other words, on a fair and reasonable construction of the Award, what the retrenched workman got is only compensation for retrenchment and not any amount by way of gratuity properly so called.

arguments.claim: The Award provides payment not only for retrenchment but also for terminations excepted from s.2(oo) definition, making it a composite scheme where retrenchment payment is compensation

anchor.surface_text: Retrenchment is defined under s. 2(oo) and means the termination by the employer of the service of a workman for any reasons whatsoever, otherwise than as a punishment inflicted by way of disciplinary action, but does not include (a) voluntary retirement... It is thus a composite scheme and merely because the payment is called gratuity even where it is payable on account of retrenchment, it cannot be anything other than compensation so far as the part of the Award relating to retrenchment is concerned.

arguments.claim: Chapter VA added to provide uniform minimum retrenchment compensation where no prior schemes existed

anchor.surface_text: Chapter VA, containing ss. 25F and 25J, with which we are concerned, was added in the Act by Act 43 of 1953, with effect from October 24, 1953. The reasons for this addition was that though there were schemes in force in many concerns for payment to workmen on retrenchment, there were many other concerns where no such schemes were in force...

arguments.claim: s.25J provides Chapter VA effective notwithstanding inconsistent laws, but proviso protects superior rights under awards; no intention for double compensation

anchor.surface_text: Then comes s. 25J, sub-s. (1) whereof provides that the provisions of Chapter VA shall have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any other law including standing orders. There is, however, a proviso... This clearly means that if by any award or contract a workman is entitled to something more as retrenchment compensation than is provided by s. 25F... It is obvious that it was not the intention of the legislature that a workman on retrenchment should get compensation twice...

arguments.claim: Gratuity on retrenchment under Award is in substance retrenchment compensation under s.25F; workmen entitled to whichever more advantageous, here s.25F

anchor.surface_text: We cannot agree with the Appellate Tribunal that the payment of gratuity in the event of retrenchment has nothing to do with the compensation payable... Whether it is called gratuity or compensation, it is in substance a payment to the workman on account of retrenchment... the workmen are only entitled to one or the other, whichever is more advantageous to them in view of s. 25J.

arguments.claim: Since s.25F compensation already paid and better than Award, no further entitlement under Award

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has already paid the compensation provided under s. 25F the workmen therefore are not entitled to anything more under the Award. We, therefore allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Appellate Tribunal and restore that of the Industrial Tribunal in this matter.

holdings.text: on a fair and reasonable construction of the Award, what the retrenched workman got is only compensation for retrenchment and not any amount by way of gratuity properly so called.

anchor.surface_text: on a fair and reasonable construction of the Award, what the retrenched workman got is only compensation for retrenchment and not any amount by way of gratuity properly so called.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Award terms limit payment to retrenchment cases with one-year service requirement and exclusion for misconduct, matching nature of retrenchment compensation.

holdings.text: It is thus a composite scheme and merely because the payment is called gratuity even where it is payable on account of retrenchment, it cannot be anything other than compensation so far as the part of the Award relating to retrenchment is concerned.

anchor.surface_text: s. 2 oo  and means the termination by the employer of the service of a workman for any reasons whatsoever, otherwise than as a punishment inflicted by way of disciplinary action, but does not include

holdings.reasoning_summary: Award covers retrenchment plus terminations excluded from s.2(oo) definition, making retrenchment portion compensation despite label.

holdings.text: It is obvious that it was not the intention of the legislature that a workman on retrenchment should get compensation twice, i.e. once under the Act and once under the scheme in force providing for retrenchment compensation, by whatever name the payment might have been called.

anchor.surface_text: Then comes s. 25J, sub-s. (1) whereof provides that the provisions of Chapter VA shall have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any other law including standing orders.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25J proviso saves superior award rights but harmonized to avoid double payment for same retrenchment loss.

holdings.text: gratuity provided therein on retrenchment is nothing more nor less than retrenchment compensation provided under s. 25F of the Act, and the workmen are only entitled to one or the other, whichever is more advantageous to them in view of s. 25J.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot agree with the Appellate Tribunal that the payment of gratuity in the event of retrenchment has nothing to do with the compensation payable...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance over form: label irrelevant; Award gratuity equivalent to s.25F; choose beneficial per s.25J.

holdings.text: the scheme of the Award in this case providing for a gratuity on retrenchment was exactly the same as compensation provided under s. 25F, and as the provisions of s. 25F are better than the provisions of the Award in respect of retrenchment the workmen would be entitled to compensation provided under s. 25F only, and not both under that section and under the Award.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we are of opinion that the Industrial Tribunal was right in holding that the scheme of the Award in this case providing for a gratuity on retrenchment was exactly the same as compensation provided under s. 25F,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct comparison shows s.25F terms superior; already paid, satisfies Award obligation.

holdings.text: the workmen therefore are not entitled to anything more under the Award.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has already paid the compensation provided under s. 25F the workmen therefore are not entitled to anything more under the Award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25F payment made and advantageous, precludes additional claim under Award.

holdings.text: The matter would be different if the scheme in force in any concern or any award provides gratuity which is different in nature from the retrenchment compensation under s. 25F.

anchor.surface_text: The matter would be different if the scheme in force in any concern or any award provides gratuity which is different in nature from the retrenchment compensation under s. 25F.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical distinction if gratuity not tied to retrenchment nature.

precedents.citation: Indian Hume Pipe Company Limited v. Its Workmen  1960  2  S.C.R. 32

anchor.surface_text: The general question has been companysidered by this Court in the Indian Hume Pipe Company Limited v. Its Workmen  1960  2  S.C.R. 32 , judgment which is being delivered today. As the penultimate paragraph in that judgment shows, special companysiderations may arise on the terms of agreements or awards in particular cases and it is this aspect which falls to be companysidered in the present appeal.

precedents.case_name: Indian Hume Pipe Company Limited v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: general question on whether retrenched workmen are entitled to gratuity under a scheme or award in addition to retrenchment compensation under s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore allow the appeal, set aside the decision of the Appellate Tribunal and restore that of the Industrial Tribunal in this matter.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed. Decision of Appellate Tribunal set aside and decision of Industrial Tribunal restored. Retrenched workmen not entitled to any gratuity under the Award over and above the retrenchment compensation under s. 25F of the Act.

restore that of the Industrial Tribunal in this matter
